elements.content: By introducing different long rigid ligands into polyoxometalate (POM) systems, four novel inorganic–organic hybrids containing multitrack Cu−N coordination polymeric chain-modified POMs, {[Cu(4,4′-bipy)]3[HGeMo12O40]}·0.5H2O (1), [Cu(4,4′-bipy)]{[Cu(4,4′-bipy)]2[W6O19]}·4H2O (2) (bipy = bipyridine), [Cu(bpe)]{[Cu(bpe)]2[GeMo12O40(VO)2]} (3) (bpe = bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene), and [Cu2(phnz)3]2[SiW12O40] (4) (phnz = phenazine), have been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by routine physical methods. The crystal structures of 1–4 have been established by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1 exhibits a tritrack Cu−N chain-modified Keggin POM 1D structure. Compound 2 represents the first example of a 2D framework constructed from a Lindquist polyoxoanion modified by double bitrack Cu−N chains via its terminal oxygen and bridge oxygen atoms. The rail-like 1D structure of compound 3 is formed from Keggin clusters modified by double monotrack Cu−N chains. Compound 4 shows a pseudo-1D structure of double monotrack Cu−N chain-modified Keggin POMs through offset face-to-face π−π stacking interactions between the adjacent phnz molecules. Investigation of their structural differences shows the important roles of the size of POMs and the unit length of the Cu−N chains in the assembly process of the solid structures. Furthermore, the electrochemical properties of 1−4 were studied.

The crystal structures of 1-4 have been established by single crystal X-ray diffraction. Compound 1 exhibits a tritrack Cu-N chain-modified Keggin POM 1D structure. Compound 2 represents the first example of a 2D framework constructed from a Lindquist polyoxoanion modified by double bitrack Cu-N chains via its terminal oxygen and bridge oxygen atoms. The rail-like 1D structure of compound 3 is formed from Keggin clusters modified by double monotrack Cu-N chains. Compound 4 shows a pseudo-1D structure of double monotrack Cu-N chain-modified Keggin POMs through offset face-to-face π-π stacking interactions between the adjacent phnz molecules. Investigation of their structural differences shows the important roles of the size of POMs and the unit length of the Cu-N chains in the assembly process of the solid structures. Furthermore, the electrochemical properties of 1-4 were studied.

elements.content: By changing the size of the POMs and the length of the ligands, four new inorganic−organic hybrids containing multiple Cu−N polymeric chain-modified POMs have been hydrothermally synthesized. The two factors have significant influence on the dimensions of the hybrids and the number of coparallel chains of Cu−pyridyl polymers.
elements.clean_text: By changing the size of the POMs and the length of the ligands, four new inorganic-organic hybrids containing multiple Cu-N polymeric chain-modified POMs have been hydrothermally synthesized. The two factors have significant influence on the dimensions of the hybrids and the number of coparallel chains of Cu-pyridyl polymers.

elements.content: The design and synthesis of organic–inorganic hybrid materials through crystal engineering have become a significant area of research for chemists because of their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies, and potential applications in molecular absorption and electron-conductive, optical, biochemical, and magnetic materials. One strategy for design of organic–inorganic hybrid materials is to select proper inorganic building block and transition metal (TM) complexes as structure-directing components. As is well-known, polyoxometalates (POMs) composed of early transition metals (V, Nb, Mo, and W) are an outstanding class of inorganic building blocks for the construction of organic–inorganic hybrid materials, which have been attracting growing interest due to their intriguing structural chemistry, unexpected reactivity, and potential applications. POMs have many surface oxygen atoms which have the capability of coordinating to the metal centers of the metal−organic skeleton. So, in recent years, a series of hybrids made of POMs associated with various TM complexes have been reported, in which the TM coordination complexes provide charge compensation and/or become a part of the inorganic POM framework. To realize a controllable synthesis selecting proper POM building blocks as templates and some interesting TM complexes as modifiers remains very important.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and synthesis of organic-inorganic hybrid materials through crystal engineering have become a significant area of research for chemists because of their intriguing variety of architectures and topologies, and potential applications in molecular absorption and electron-conductive, optical, biochemical, and magnetic materials. One strategy for design of organic-inorganic hybrid materials is to select proper inorganic building block and transition metal (TM) complexes as structure-directing components. As is well-known, polyoxometalates (POMs) composed of early transition metals (V, Nb, Mo, and W) are an outstanding class of inorganic building blocks for the construction of organic-inorganic hybrid materials, which have been attracting growing interest due to their intriguing structural chemistry, unexpected reactivity, and potential applications. POMs have many surface oxygen atoms which have the capability of coordinating to the metal centers of the metal-organic skeleton. So, in recent years, a series of hybrids made of POMs associated with various TM complexes have been reported, in which the TM coordination complexes provide charge compensation and/or become a part of the inorganic POM framework. To realize a controllable synthesis selecting proper POM building blocks as templates and some interesting TM complexes as modifiers remains very important.

elements.content: In our previous work, we reported two Keggin POMs modified by multitrack Cu(bipy) chains. The structures of the two compounds implied that the sizes of the POMs can affect the dimension of the hybrid materials and the number of coparallel multichains of the Cu−N coordination polymer. However, it would take more examples to rationalize the results. In present work, we select Keggin and Lindqvist clusters, the ligands 4,4′-bipy, bpe, and phnz (Scheme ), and Cu ion to build TM coordination complexes, in hopes of getting more role information for these components in the assembly of extended structures of multitrack Cu−N chain-modified POMs. The following points are taken into consideration: (1) there is a significant difference between the sizes of the Keggin and Lindqvist clusters, (2) the linear 4,4′-bipy, bpe, and phnz ligands possess the same type of two terminal pyridyl groups but different spacers, and (3) the d10 ions, so-called soft Lewis acidic metal ions, generally show variable coordination numbers and tunable coordination spheres.

elements.content: Herein, we report the hydrothermal synthesis and crystal structures of four new Cu−N coordination polymeric chain-modified POM derivatives, {[Cu(4,4′-bipy)]3[HGeMo12O40]}·0.5H2O (1), [Cu(4,4′-bipy)]{[Cu(4,4′-bipy)]2[W6O19]}·4H2O (2), [Cu(bpe)]{[Cu(bpe)]2[GeMo12O40(VO)2]} (3), and [Cu2(phnz)3]2[SiW12O40] (4). The successful isolation of the four compounds shows the importance of the different sizes of POMs and the different unit lengths of Cu−N coordination polymeric chains in the assembly process of the solid structures.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report the hydrothermal synthesis and crystal structures of four new Cu-N coordination polymeric chain-modified POM derivatives, {[Cu(4,4'-bipy)]3[HGeMo12O40]}⋅0.5H2O (1), [Cu(4,4'-bipy)]{[Cu(4,4'-bipy)]2[W6O19]}⋅4H2O (2), [Cu(bpe)]{[Cu(bpe)]2[GeMo12O40(VO)2]} (3), and [Cu2(phnz)3]2[SiW12O40] (4). The successful isolation of the four compounds shows the importance of the different sizes of POMs and the different unit lengths of Cu-N coordination polymeric chains in the assembly process of the solid structures.

elements.content: All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrometer with KBr pellets in the 400–4000 cm−1 region. XPS analyses were performed on a VGESCALABMK spectrometer with an Mg Kα (1253.6 eV) achromatic X-ray source. The vacuum inside the analysis chamber was maintained at 6.2 × 10−6 Pa during analysis. The TG analyses were performed on a DTG-60AH instrument for 1–3 and a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument for 4 in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Cyclic voltammograms were obtained with a CHI 660 electrochemical workstation at room temperature. Platinum gauze was used as a counter electrode, and a Ag/AgCl electrode was referenced. Chemically bulk-modified carbon paste electrodes (CPEs) were used as working electrodes.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All reagents were purchased commercially and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (C, H, and N) were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 CHN elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were obtained on an Alpha Centaurt FT/IR spectrometer with KBr pellets in the 400-4000 cm-1 region. XPS analyses were performed on a VGESCALABMK spectrometer with an Mg Kα (1253.6 eV) achromatic X-ray source. The vacuum inside the analysis chamber was maintained at 6.2 × 10-6 Pa during analysis. The TG analyses were performed on a DTG-60AH instrument for 1-3 and a Perkin-Elmer TGA7 instrument for 4 in flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. Cyclic voltammograms were obtained with a CHI 660 electrochemical workstation at room temperature. Platinum gauze was used as a counter electrode, and a Ag/AgCl electrode was referenced. Chemically bulk-modified carbon paste electrodes (CPEs) were used as working electrodes.

elements.content: The starting materials α-H4[GeMo12O40]·xH2O (1 mmol, 202 mg) 4,4-bipy (1 mmol, 20 mg), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (2 mmol, 48 mg), triethylamine (trea) (1 mmol), NH4VO3 (1 mmol, 12 mg), and distilled water (9 mL) were mixed. The resulting suspension was stirred for 1 h, the pH was adjusted to 4.7 with 1 M NaOH, and the suspension was sealed in an 18 mL Telfon-lined reactor. After 6 days of heating at 160 °C, the reactor was slow cooled to room temperature over a period of 16 h. Black-brown-like block crystals of 1 were filtered, washed with water, and dried at room temperature. Yield: ca. 28% based on Mo. Anal. Calcd for C30H24Cu3GeMo12N6O40.5 (2531.1): C, 14.26; H, 0.95; N, 3.31 (%). Found: C, 14.22; H, 1.07; N, 3.11.

elements.content: In the synthesis of compounds 1–4, the oxidation state of copper was changed from the reactant copper(II) ion to the resultant copper(I) ion, which was confirmed by charge neutrality, coordination environments, valence sum calculations, and XPS. Such a phenomenon was often observed in the reaction of an N-containing ligand with the copper(II) ion under hydrothermal conditions.

elements.content: Crystal data for compounds 1–4 were collected on Rigaku RAXIS RAPID IP and Bruker SMART-CCD diffractometers, with Mo Kα monochromatic radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. All structures were solved by the directed methods and refined by full matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL crystallographic software package. All the nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The positions of hydrogen atoms on carbon atoms were calculated theoretically. The crystal data and structure refinement of compounds 1–4 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables S1–S4 of the .

X-ray Crystallographic Study

Crystal data for compounds 1-4 were collected on Rigaku RAXIS RAPID IP and Bruker SMART-CCD diffractometers, with Mo Kα monochromatic radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. All structures were solved by the directed methods and refined by full matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXTL crystallographic software package. All the nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The positions of hydrogen atoms on carbon atoms were calculated theoretically. The crystal data and structure refinement of compounds 1-4 are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Tables S1-S4 of the .

A compound 1-modified carbon paste electrode 1-CPE was prepared by the following method: 48 mg of graphite powder and 8 mg of compound 1 were mixed and ground together with an agate mortar and pestle to achieve a uniform mixture, and then 0.6 mL of Nujol was added with stirring. The homogenized mixture was packed into a glass tube with a 1.2 mm inner diameter, and the tube surface was wiped with paper. Electrical contact was established with a copper rod through the back of the electrode. In a similar manner, 2-, 3-, and 4-CPEs were made with 2, 3, and 4.
elements.clean_text:
Preparations of 1-, 2-, 3-, and 4-CPEs

A compound 1-modified carbon paste electrode 1-CPE was prepared by the following method: 48 mg of graphite powder and 8 mg of compound 1 were mixed and ground together with an agate mortar and pestle to achieve a uniform mixture, and then 0.6 mL of Nujol was added with stirring. The homogenized mixture was packed into a glass tube with a 1.2 mm inner diameter, and the tube surface was wiped with paper. Electrical contact was established with a copper rod through the back of the electrode. In a similar manner, 2-, 3-, and 4-CPEs were made with 2, 3, and 4.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 consists of one Keggin type [GeMo12O40]4- (GeMo12) anion, three crystallographically independent Cu atoms and 4,4′-bipy molecules, and half of a water molecule. Each Cu atom adopts a trigonal geometry coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of two 4,4′-bipy ligands and one oxygen atom of the [GeMo12O40]4- anion. In this way, each 4,4′-bipy ligand links two symmetrical CuI atoms into a Cu-4,4′-bipy polymeric chain, and each GeMo12 cluster acts as an inorganic tridentate ligand covalently bonding to three parallel Cu-4,4′-bipy subunits through linearly arrayed O17, O28, and O40 units of a Mo3O13 triad (Mo4, Mo5, and Mo6), as shown in Figure a. The Keggin clusters become pendants of the tritrack Cu(bipy) chains, projecting toward two sides (Figure b). The bond distances around the three Cu(I) ions are 2.420(9) Å (Cu1−O17), 2.348(9) Å (Cu2−O40), 2.301(9) Å (Cu3−O28), 1.887(11)–1.896(11) Å (Cu1−N), 1.890(10)–1.895(10) Å (Cu2−N), and 1.875(11)–1.915(10) Å (Cu3−N), while the N−Cu−N angles are in the range 164.3 (5)–166.5(5)°, and the N−Cu−O angles are in the range 95.1(4)–98.4(4)°.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Descriptions of 1 

Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 consists of one Keggin type [GeMo12O40]4- (GeMo12) anion, three crystallographically independent Cu atoms and 4,4'-bipy molecules, and half of a water molecule. Each Cu atom adopts a trigonal geometry coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of two 4,4'-bipy ligands and one oxygen atom of the [GeMo12O40]4- anion. In this way, each 4,4'-bipy ligand links two symmetrical CuI atoms into a Cu-4,4'-bipy polymeric chain, and each GeMo12 cluster acts as an inorganic tridentate ligand covalently bonding to three parallel Cu-4,4'-bipy subunits through linearly arrayed O17, O28, and O40 units of a Mo3O13 triad (Mo4, Mo5, and Mo6), as shown in Figure a. The Keggin clusters become pendants of the tritrack Cu(bipy) chains, projecting toward two sides (Figure b). The bond distances around the three Cu(I) ions are 2.420(9) Å (Cu1-O17), 2.348(9) Å (Cu2-O40), 2.301(9) Å (Cu3-O28), 1.887(11)-1.896(11) Å (Cu1-N), 1.890(10)-1.895(10) Å (Cu2-N), and 1.875(11)-1.915(10) Å (Cu3-N), while the N-Cu-N angles are in the range 164.3 (5)-166.5(5)°, and the N-Cu-O angles are in the range 95.1(4)-98.4(4)°.

elements.content: Compound 2 is composed of one Lindquist type [W6O19]3− (W6) anion, three 4,4′-bipy molecules, four water molecules, and three Cu atoms, which form three Cu(4,4′-bipy) moieties (Figure a). The Cu(1) atom is coordinated by two N atoms from two 4,4′-bipy molecules to form an isolated polymeric chain. The Cu(2) atom adopts a distorted square planar coordination geometry established by two nitrogen atoms of two 4,4′-bipy ligands and two oxygen atoms of two different W6 clusters. The W6 cluster acts as a tetradentate ligand covalently bonding to four Cu(4,4′-bipy) complexes via its four centrally symmetric bridging oxygen (O8) and terminal oxygen (O1) atoms, respectively, resulting in a rare double bitrack Cu(4,4′-bipy) chains modified Lindqvist polymeric compound, shown in Figure b. The bond distances around the CuI ions are 2.633(9) Å (Cu2−O1), 2.696(9) Å (Cu2−O8), 1.900 Å (Cu1−N1), and 1.898(1)–1.901(11) Å (Cu2−N), while the N−Cu−N angles are in the range 176.2(6)−180.0(2)°. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of a new 2D framework that is formed by Lindquist polyoxoanion modified by transition metal coordination polymeric chains simultaneously via its terminal oxygen and bridge oxygen atoms. Furthermore, Cu(1)−4,4′-bipy chains link a 2D layer into a 3D structure via π−π interactions between the adjacent bipy molecules with the shortest distance 3.305 Å (Figure S1).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Descriptions of 2 

Compound 2 is composed of one Lindquist type [W6O19]3- (W6) anion, three 4,4'-bipy molecules, four water molecules, and three Cu atoms, which form three Cu(4,4'-bipy) moieties (Figure a). The Cu(1) atom is coordinated by two N atoms from two 4,4'-bipy molecules to form an isolated polymeric chain. The Cu(2) atom adopts a distorted square planar coordination geometry established by two nitrogen atoms of two 4,4'-bipy ligands and two oxygen atoms of two different W6 clusters. The W6 cluster acts as a tetradentate ligand covalently bonding to four Cu(4,4'-bipy) complexes via its four centrally symmetric bridging oxygen (O8) and terminal oxygen (O1) atoms, respectively, resulting in a rare double bitrack Cu(4,4'-bipy) chains modified Lindqvist polymeric compound, shown in Figure b. The bond distances around the CuI ions are 2.633(9) Å (Cu2-O1), 2.696(9) Å (Cu2-O8), 1.900 Å (Cu1-N1), and 1.898(1)-1.901(11) Å (Cu2-N), while the N-Cu-N angles are in the range 176.2(6)-180.0(2)°. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of a new 2D framework that is formed by Lindquist polyoxoanion modified by transition metal coordination polymeric chains simultaneously via its terminal oxygen and bridge oxygen atoms. Furthermore, Cu(1)-4,4'-bipy chains link a 2D layer into a 3D structure via π-π interactions between the adjacent bipy molecules with the shortest distance 3.305 Å (Figure S1).

elements.content: Compound 3 consists of one [GeMo12O40(VO)2]3− (GeMo12V2), three bpe molecules, and three Cu atoms, which form three [Cu(bpe)]+ cations shown in Figure a. The Cu(1) atom adopts a nearly linear coordination geometry with two N atoms from two bpe molecules to form an isolated polymeric chain with the bond distance 1.901 Å (Cu1−N2) and the N−Cu−N bond angle 180°. The Cu(2) atom adopts a trigonal geometry coordinated by two N atoms of two bpe ligands and one O atom (O23) of GeMo12V2, similar to compound 1. So each bpe ligand links two symmetric Cu(2) atoms into a Cu−bpe polymeric chain. The GeMo12V2 cluster acting as a bidentate ligand covalently links to two CuI centers via its centrally symmetric terminal oxygen (O23) atom, resulting in a “rail-like” double monotrack Cu−bpe chain modified Keggin POMs as illustrated in Figure b. The bond distances around the Cu(I) ion are 2.656(4) Å (Cu−O23), 1.879 Å (Cu−N3), and 1.892 Å (Cu2−N1), while the N−Cu−N angle is 172.95° and the N−Cu−O angles are in the range 89.01–95.44°. Furthermore, the Cu(1)−bpe polymeric chain links the neighboring “rail-like” chain via the stronger interaction with the distance 2.863 Å (Cu1···O23), resulting in a layer structure as illustrated in Figure S2.

elements.content: Compound 4 consists of one [SiW12O40]4− (SiW12) anion and two [Cu2(phnz)3]2+ cations. There are two crystallographically independent CuI atoms (Cu1, Cu2), and they exhibit the same trigonal geometry coordinated by two nitrogen atoms of two phnz ligands and one terminal oxygen atom of the polyoxoanions. Due to the SiW12 clusters’ steric hindrance, the three phnz molecules link two Cu atoms, forming a [Cu2(phnz)3] unit. SiW12, acting as a tetradentate ligand, covalently links to four CuI centers of two units of [Cu2(phnz)3] via its terminal oxygen atoms, to form a discrete [Cu2(phnz)3]2[SiW12O40] molecule (Figure a). The bond distances around the Cu ions are 2.159 Å (Cu1−O2), 2.150 Å (Cu2−O1), 1.966 Å (Cu1−N5), 2.004 Å (Cu1−N4), 1.943 Å (Cu2−N1), and 2.006 Å (Cu2−N3), while the N−Cu−N angle is 172.95° and the N−Cu−O angles are in the range (89.01–95.44°). Furthermore, a pseudochain structure is formed through offset face-to-face π−π interactions between the adjacent phnz molecules with the shortest distance 3.356 Å, as shown in Figure b.

elements.content: The main feature of compound 1 is that the tritrack chains with GeMo12 pendants “zipper” array in the same manner as that for {[Cu(4,4′-bipy)]3[HSiMo12O40]}·1.5H2O with a small difference (Figure S3 in the ), to form an infinite 2D supramolecular structure (Figure a), while compound 2 features a “side by side” array of W6O19 clusters (Figure b). The differences in the structures between 1 and 2 are attributable to the different sizes of the polyoxoanions; namely, the spherical diameter of the W6 cluster (ca. 8.0 Å) is smaller than that of the GeMo12 cluster (ca. 10.0 Å). Due to the POM steric hindrance, the unit length of the Cu(bipy) chains can accommodate GeMo12 clusters in an “up and down” array to form a chain structure in compound 1 and can accommodate W6 clusters in a “side by side” array to form a layer structure in compound 2. Perhaps due to the same reason, W6 clusters are modified by doubly bitrack Cu(4,4′-bipy) chains, while GeMo12 clusters are modified by tritrack Cu(4,4′-bipy) chains.

The differences in the structures between 1 and 2 are attributable to the different sizes of the polyoxoanions; namely, the spherical diameter of the W6 cluster (ca. 8.0 Å) is smaller than that of the GeMo12 cluster (ca. 10.0 Å). Due to the POM steric hindrance, the unit length of the Cu(bipy) chains can accommodate GeMo12 clusters in an "up and down" array to form a chain structure in compound 1 and can accommodate W6 clusters in a "side by side" array to form a layer structure in compound 2. elements.content: In comparison with the structures of compounds 1, 3, and 4, all of them are Keggin polyoxoanions with unobvious differences in size but significant differences in the unit length of the Cu−N coordination polymeric chains. The increased order of the unit length of the Cu−L chains is as follows: Cu−bpe (13.108 Å) > Cu−bipy (10.880 Å) > Cu−phnz (6.649 Å). This will certainly lead to their structural differences, although the three ligands possess the same type of two-terminal donor N atoms. As mentioned above, compound 1 forms a 1D structure, in which GeMo12 clusters array “up and down” along the tritrack Cu−bipy chains (Figure a). In compound 3, the unit length of the Cu−bpe chain is longer than that of the Cu−bipy chain, so the Cu−bpe chain can accommodate the GeMo12V2 cluster in a “side by side” arrangement (Figure b), whereas the shortest unit length of the Cu−phnz group could not match that of a big SiW12 cluster; thus, a discrete [Cu2(phnz)3]2[SiW12O40] molecule forms. The 1D structure of compound 4 is established through the offset face-to-face π−π interactions between the adjacent phnz molecules (Figure c). These results indicate that the different lengths of the spacers in the organic ligands can significantly affect the assembling of multitrack Cu−N coordination polymeric chain-modified POMs.
elements.clean_text:
Influence of the Length of Ligands on the Structures of Multitrack Cu-N Coordination Polymeric Chain-Modified POMs

In comparison with the structures of compounds 1, 3, and 4, all of them are Keggin polyoxoanions with unobvious differences in size but significant differences in the unit length of the Cu-N coordination polymeric chains. The increased order of the unit length of the Cu-L chains is as follows: Cu-bpe (13.108 Å) > Cu-bipy (10.880 Å) > Cu-phnz (6.649 Å). This will certainly lead to their structural differences, although the three ligands possess the same type of two-terminal donor N atoms. As mentioned above, compound 1 forms a 1D structure, in which GeMo12 clusters array "up and down" along the tritrack Cu-bipy chains (Figure a). In compound 3, the unit length of the Cu-bpe chain is longer than that of the Cu-bipy chain, so the Cu-bpe chain can accommodate the GeMo12V2 cluster in a "side by side" arrangement (Figure b), whereas the shortest unit length of the Cu-phnz group could not match that of a big SiW12 cluster; thus, a discrete [Cu2(phnz)3]2[SiW12O40] molecule forms. The 1D structure of compound 4 is established through the offset face-to-face π-π interactions between the adjacent phnz molecules (Figure c). These results indicate that the different lengths of the spacers in the organic ligands can significantly affect the assembling of multitrack Cu-N coordination polymeric chain-modified POMs.

elements.content: In the IR spectra (Figure S4a−d in the ), characteristic peaks at 953, 902, and 784 cm−1 for compound 1 and at 940, 875, and 775 cm−1 for compound 3 are attributed to νas(Mo−Od), νas(Mo−Ob−Mo),and νas(Mo−Oc−Mo), and are nearly identical to those of [GeMo12O40]4− except for slight changes in peak position, perhaps due to coordination. For compound 2, the characteristic peaks at 948.82, 790.68, 583.76, and 446.10 cm−1 are attributed to ν(W−Od), ν(W−Ob−W), δ(W−Ob−W), and δ(W−Oc) of the [W6O19]3− polyoxoanion, respectively. In the IR spectrum of compound 4, the characteristic peaks at 791, 919, 963, and 1012 cm-1 are attributed to ν(W−Oc−W), ν(W−Ob−W), ν(W−Od), and ν(Si−Oa) of the [SiW12O40]4− polyoxoanion, respectively. Furthermore, a series of characteristic bands in the 1410−1730 cm-1 region are associated with 4,4′-bipy, bpe, and phnz groups.

In the IR spectra (Figure S4a-d in the ), characteristic peaks at 953, 902, and 784 cm-1 for compound 1 and at 940, 875, and 775 cm-1 for compound 3 are attributed to νas(Mo-Od), νas(Mo-Ob-Mo),and νas(Mo-Oc-Mo), and are nearly identical to those of [GeMo12O40]4- except for slight changes in peak position, perhaps due to coordination. For compound 2, the characteristic peaks at 948.82, 790.68, 583.76, and 446.10 cm-1 are attributed to ν(W-Od), ν(W-Ob-W), δ(W-Ob-W), and δ(W-Oc) of the [W6O19]3- polyoxoanion, respectively. In the IR spectrum of compound 4, the characteristic peaks at 791, 919, 963, and 1012 cm-1 are attributed to ν(W-Oc-W), ν(W-Ob-W), ν(W-Od), and ν(Si-Oa) of the [SiW12O40]4- polyoxoanion, respectively. Furthermore, a series of characteristic bands in the 1410-1730 cm-1 region are associated with 4,4'-bipy, bpe, and phnz groups.

elements.content: The bond valence sum calculations (BVS) indicate that all copper atoms are in the +1 oxidation state in compounds 1–4, while all molybdenum atoms are in the +6 oxidation state in 1, one out of six tungsten atoms are in the +5 oxidation state in 2, three out of twelve Mo atoms are in the +5 oxidation state in 3, and all tungsten atoms are in the +6 oxidation state in 4, which are supported by the XPS measurements. The XPS spectra exhibit two peaks at 933.4/933.6 and 953.8/953.5 eV, attributed to Cu+2p3/2 and Cu+2p5/2 for compounds 2 and 3, two peaks at 35.0 eV and 33.4 eV attributed to W6+ and W5+ for 2, two overlapping peaks at 232.1 and 231.4 eV attributed to Mo6+ and Mo5+, and a peak at 516.2 eV attributed to V4+ for 3. All these results further confirm the structure analysis (Figure S5 of the ).

elements.content: The TGA measurements also support the chemical composition (Figure S6a−d of the ). For compound 1, TGA shows that the weight loss starts at 105 °C and ends at 445 °C (ca. 18.98%), which is ascribed to the removal of lattice water molecules and the decomposition of 4,4′-bipy ligands (calc 18.85%). The TGA of 2 shows a two-step weight loss: the first weight loss of 3.76% (calc 3.38%) from 95 to 155 °C may be assigned to the removal of H2O, and the second weight loss of 21.64% (calc 21.89%) at 155–619 °C may be ascribed to decomposition of 4,4′-bipy ligands. Compounds 3 and 4 all undergo one-step weight loss of 20.24% (calc 19.96%) from 320 to 638 °C for 3 and 25.54% (calc 25.66%) from 275 to 470 °C for 4, which can be ascribed to the decomposition of bpe and phnz ligands, respectively.

elements.content: The redox properties of compounds 1–4 were studied in 0.1 M H2SO4 aqueous solution at the scan rate 50 mV s−1 and are shown in Figure . In the potential range from +1000 to −100 mV, there are three pairs of reversible redox peaks at +77.68, +282.03, and +402.79 mV, of E 1/2 = (E cp + E ap)/2 for 1-CPE, and four redox peaks at +64, +207, +348, and +587 mV for 3-CPE, respectively. The redox peaks I−I′, II−II′, and III−III′ correspond to three consecutive two-electron processes of Mo. The redox peak IV−IV′ should be ascribed to the one-electron redox process of V(V/IV). The different E 1/2 values of Mo for 1 and 3 may be caused by the {VO} units capping the two opposite pits of the GeMo12 clusters. In the potential range from −600 to +600 mV for 2-CPE, and from −800 to +300 mV for 4-CPE, there are two pairs (I−I′ and II−II′) of reversible redox peaks at E 1/2 = −106 and −343 mV for 2-CPE and at −680 and −511 mV for 4-CPE, which should be ascribed to the one-electron redox process of W. The third irreversible anodic peak (III) is assigned to the oxidation of Cu I at 112 mV for 2-CPE and at 65 mV for 4-CPE.

In the potential range from +1000 to -100 mV, there are three pairs of reversible redox peaks at +77.68, +282.03, and +402.79 mV, of E 1/2 = (E cp + E ap)/2 for 1-CPE, and four redox peaks at +64, +207, +348, and +587 mV for 3-CPE, respectively. The redox peaks I-I', II-II', and III-III' correspond to three consecutive two-electron processes of Mo. The redox peak IV-IV' should be ascribed to the one-electron redox process of V(V/IV). The different E 1/2 values of Mo for 1 and 3 may be caused by the {VO} units capping the two opposite pits of the GeMo12 clusters. In the potential range from -600 to +600 mV for 2-CPE, and from -800 to +300 mV for 4-CPE, there are two pairs (I-I' and II-II') of reversible redox peaks at E 1/2 = -106 and -343 mV for 2-CPE and at -680 and -511 mV for 4-CPE, which should be ascribed to the one-electron redox process of W. elements.content: In this paper, using presynthesized POMs, soft Lewis acidic metal Cu ions, and the linear 4,4′-bipy, bpe, and phnz ligands, four new POM derivatives have been isolated. The CuI ions in compounds 1–4 show variable coordination numbers and present a nearly linear coordination with the nitrogen atoms in the Cu−N coordination polymeric chains, giving a 2(N) + 0(O) linear-type geometry (in compounds 2 and 3), a 2(N) + 1(O) T-type geometry (in compounds 1, 3, and 4), and a 2(N) + 2(O) seesaw-type geometry (in compound 2). The informative structures of the four compounds indicate that the different sizes of the POMs and the different lengths of the ligands have a significant influence on the dimensions of the hybrids and the number of coparallel chains of Cu−pyridyl polymers, namely, a tritrack chain structure for 1, a double bitrack layer structure for 2, a double monotrack chain structure for 3, and a pseudodouble monotrack chain structure for 4. These four examples show the perspective of extending the POM family through reasonable selection of the POM clusters and organic ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this paper, using presynthesized POMs, soft Lewis acidic metal Cu ions, and the linear 4,4'-bipy, bpe, and phnz ligands, four new POM derivatives have been isolated. The CuI ions in compounds 1-4 show variable coordination numbers and present a nearly linear coordination with the nitrogen atoms in the Cu-N coordination polymeric chains, giving a 2(N) + 0(O) linear-type geometry (in compounds 2 and 3), a 2(N) + 1(O) T-type geometry (in compounds 1, 3, and 4), and a 2(N) + 2(O) seesaw-type geometry (in compound 2). The informative structures of the four compounds indicate that the different sizes of the POMs and the different lengths of the ligands have a significant influence on the dimensions of the hybrids and the number of coparallel chains of Cu-pyridyl polymers, namely, a tritrack chain structure for 1, a double bitrack layer structure for 2, a double monotrack chain structure for 3, and a pseudodouble monotrack chain structure for 4. These four examples show the perspective of extending the POM family through reasonable selection of the POM clusters and organic ligands.

The starting materials α-H4[GeMo12O40]·xH2O (1 mmol, 202 mg) 4,4-bipy (1 mmol, 20 mg), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (2 mmol, 48 mg), triethylamine (trea) (1 mmol), NH4VO3 (1 mmol, 12 mg), and distilled water (9 mL) were mixed. The resulting suspension was stirred for 1 h, the pH was adjusted to 4.7 with 1 M NaOH, and the suspension was sealed in an 18 mL Telfon-lined reactor. After 6 days of heating at 160 °C, the reactor was slow cooled to room temperature over a period of 16 h. Black-brown-like block crystals of 1 were filtered, washed with water, and dried at room temperature. Yield: ca. 28% based on Mo. Anal. Calcd for C30H24Cu3GeMo12N6O40.5 (2531.1): C, 14.26; H, 0.95; N, 3.31 (%). Found: C, 14.22; H, 1.07; N, 3.11.

[Cu(4,4′-bipy)]{[Cu(4,4′-bipy)]<sub>2</sub>[W<sub>6</sub>O<sub>19</sub>]}·4H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of [(C4H9)4N]2[W6O19] (1 mmol, 19 mg), 4,4-bipy (1 mmol, 20 mg), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (3 mmol, 73 mg), oxalic acid (1 mmol, 13 mg), and distilled water (9 mL) was mixed. The resulting suspension was stirred for 1 h, the pH was adjusted to 4.5 with 1 M NaOH, and the suspension was sealed in an 18 mL Telfon-lined reactor. After 6 days of heating at 160 °C, the reactor was slow cooled to room temperature over a period of 16 h. Brown-like block crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 36% based on W. Anal. Calcd for C30H32Cu3N6O23W6 (2138.28): C, 16.83; H, 1.50; N, 3.93. Found: C, 16.96; H, 1.59; N, 4.01.

[Cu(bpe)]{[Cu(bpe)]<sub>2</sub>·[GeMo<sub>12</sub>O<sub>40</sub>(VO)<sub>2</sub>]} (<bold>3</bold>)

Compound 3 was prepared in a manner similar to that described for 1 except that bpe replaced the bipy ligand. Yield: 17% based on Mo. Anal. Calcd for C36H30Cu3GeMo12N6O42V2 (2735.08): C, 15.80; H, 1.10; N, 3.07. Found: C, 15.67; H, 1.02; N, 3.12.

[Cu<sub>2</sub>(phnz)<sub>3</sub>]<sub>2</sub>[SiW<sub>12</sub>O<sub>40</sub>] (<bold>4</bold>)

A mixture of H4[GeW12O40]·xH2O (1 mmol, 202 mg), phnz (1 mmol, 35 mg), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (2 mmol, 48 mg), trea (1 mmol), NH4VO3 (1 mmol, 12 mg), and distilled water (9 mL) was mixed. The resulting suspension was stirred for 1 h, the pH was adjusted to 4.2 with 1 M NaOH, and the suspension was sealed in an 18 mL Telfon-lined reactor. After 6 days of heating at 160 °C, the reactor was slow cooled to room temperature over a period of 16 h. Black-brown-like block crystals of 4 were filtered, washed with water, and dried at room temperature. Yield: 20% based on W. Anal. Calcd for C72H48Cu4N12SiW12O40 (4209): C, 20.53; H, 1.14; N, 3.99. Found: C, 19.98; H, 1.21; N, 3.92.

Preparations of <bold>1</bold>-, <bold>2</bold>-, <bold>3</bold>-, and <bold>4</bold>-CPEs

A compound 1-modified carbon paste electrode 1-CPE was prepared by the following method: 48 mg of graphite powder and 8 mg of compound 1 were mixed and ground together with an agate mortar and pestle to achieve a uniform mixture, and then 0.6 mL of Nujol was added with stirring. The homogenized mixture was packed into a glass tube with a 1.2 mm inner diameter, and the tube surface was wiped with paper. Electrical contact was established with a copper rod through the back of the electrode. In a similar manner, 2-, 3-, and 4-CPEs were made with 2, 3, and 4.

Synthesis

{[Cu(4,4'-bipy)]3[α-HGeMo12O40]}⋅0.5H2O (1)

The starting materials α-H4[GeMo12O40]⋅xH2O (1 mmol, 202 mg) 4,4-bipy (1 mmol, 20 mg), Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (2 mmol, 48 mg), triethylamine (trea) (1 mmol), NH4VO3 (1 mmol, 12 mg), and distilled water (9 mL) were mixed. The resulting suspension was stirred for 1 h, the pH was adjusted to 4.7 with 1 M NaOH, and the suspension was sealed in an 18 mL Telfon-lined reactor. After 6 days of heating at 160 °C, the reactor was slow cooled to room temperature over a period of 16 h. Black-brown-like block crystals of 1 were filtered, washed with water, and dried at room temperature. Yield: ca. 28% based on Mo. Anal. Calcd for C30H24Cu3GeMo12N6O40.5 (2531.1): C, 14.26; H, 0.95; N, 3.31 (%). Found: C, 14.22; H, 1.07; N, 3.11.

[Cu(4,4'-bipy)]{[Cu(4,4'-bipy)]2[W6O19]}⋅4H2O (2)

A mixture of [(C4H9)4N]2[W6O19] (1 mmol, 19 mg), 4,4-bipy (1 mmol, 20 mg), Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (3 mmol, 73 mg), oxalic acid (1 mmol, 13 mg), and distilled water (9 mL) was mixed. The resulting suspension was stirred for 1 h, the pH was adjusted to 4.5 with 1 M NaOH, and the suspension was sealed in an 18 mL Telfon-lined reactor. After 6 days of heating at 160 °C, the reactor was slow cooled to room temperature over a period of 16 h. Brown-like block crystals of 2 were obtained. Yield: 36% based on W. Anal. Calcd for C30H32Cu3N6O23W6 (2138.28): C, 16.83; H, 1.50; N, 3.93. Found: C, 16.96; H, 1.59; N, 4.01.

[Cu(bpe)]{[Cu(bpe)]2⋅[GeMo12O40(VO)2]} (3)

Compound 3 was prepared in a manner similar to that described for 1 except that bpe replaced the bipy ligand. Yield: 17% based on Mo. Anal. Calcd for C36H30Cu3GeMo12N6O42V2 (2735.08): C, 15.80; H, 1.10; N, 3.07. Found: C, 15.67; H, 1.02; N, 3.12.

[Cu2(phnz)3]2[SiW12O40] (4)

A mixture of H4[GeW12O40]⋅xH2O (1 mmol, 202 mg), phnz (1 mmol, 35 mg), Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (2 mmol, 48 mg), trea (1 mmol), NH4VO3 (1 mmol, 12 mg), and distilled water (9 mL) was mixed. The resulting suspension was stirred for 1 h, the pH was adjusted to 4.2 with 1 M NaOH, and the suspension was sealed in an 18 mL Telfon-lined reactor. After 6 days of heating at 160 °C, the reactor was slow cooled to room temperature over a period of 16 h. Black-brown-like block crystals of 4 were filtered, washed with water, and dried at room temperature. Yield: 20% based on W. Anal. Calcd for C72H48Cu4N12SiW12O40 (4209): C, 20.53; H, 1.14; N, 3.99. Found: C, 19.98; H, 1.21; N, 3.92.

Preparations of 1-, 2-, 3-, and 4-CPEs

A compound 1-modified carbon paste electrode 1-CPE was prepared by the following method: 48 mg of graphite powder and 8 mg of compound 1 were mixed and ground together with an agate mortar and pestle to achieve a uniform mixture, and then 0.6 mL of Nujol was added with stirring. The homogenized mixture was packed into a glass tube with a 1.2 mm inner diameter, and the tube surface was wiped with paper. Electrical contact was established with a copper rod through the back of the electrode. In a similar manner, 2-, 3-, and 4-CPEs were made with 2, 3, and 4.

cln_elements.content:
The TGA measurements also support the chemical composition (Figure S6a−d of the ). For compound 1, TGA shows that the weight loss starts at 105 °C and ends at 445 °C (ca. 18.98%), which is ascribed to the removal of lattice water molecules and the decomposition of 4,4′-bipy ligands (calc 18.85%). The TGA of 2 shows a two-step weight loss: the first weight loss of 3.76% (calc 3.38%) from 95 to 155 °C may be assigned to the removal of H2O, and the second weight loss of 21.64% (calc 21.89%) at 155–619 °C may be ascribed to decomposition of 4,4′-bipy ligands. Compounds 3 and 4 all undergo one-step weight loss of 20.24% (calc 19.96%) from 320 to 638 °C for 3 and 25.54% (calc 25.66%) from 275 to 470 °C for 4, which can be ascribed to the decomposition of bpe and phnz ligands, respectively.

Cyclic Voltammetry

The redox properties of compounds 1–4 were studied in 0.1 M H2SO4 aqueous solution at the scan rate 50 mV s−1 and are shown in Figure . In the potential range from +1000 to −100 mV, there are three pairs of reversible redox peaks at +77.68, +282.03, and +402.79 mV, of E 1/2 = (E cp + E ap)/2 for 1-CPE, and four redox peaks at +64, +207, +348, and +587 mV for 3-CPE, respectively. The redox peaks I−I′, II−II′, and III−III′ correspond to three consecutive two-electron processes of Mo. The redox peak IV−IV′ should be ascribed to the one-electron redox process of V(V/IV). The different E 1/2 values of Mo for 1 and 3 may be caused by the {VO} units capping the two opposite pits of the GeMo12 clusters. In the potential range from −600 to +600 mV for 2-CPE, and from −800 to +300 mV for 4-CPE, there are two pairs (I−I′ and II−II′) of reversible redox peaks at E 1/2 = −106 and −343 mV for 2-CPE and at −680 and −511 mV for 4-CPE, which should be ascribed to the one-electron redox process of W. The third irreversible anodic peak (III) is assigned to the oxidation of Cu I at 112 mV for 2-CPE and at 65 mV for 4-CPE.
